title: Dynamic compression of the airways
text:
Dynamic compression of the airways results when <a href="intrapleural%20pressure">intrapleural pressure</a> equals or exceeds <a href="alveolar%20pressure">alveolar pressure</a>, which causes dynamic collapsing of the <a href="lung">lung</a> airways. It is termed "dynamic" given the <a href="transpulmonary%20pressure">transpulmonary pressure</a> (alveolar pressure − intrapleural pressure) varies based on factors including <a href="lung%20volume">lung volume</a>, <a href="Pulmonary%20compliance">compliance</a>, <a href="Airway%20resistance">resistance</a>, existing pathologies, etc.
It occurs during forced <a href="Exhalation">expiration</a> when intrapleural pressure is greater than <a href="atmospheric%20pressure">atmospheric pressure</a> (positive <a href="barometric">barometric</a> values), and not during passive expiration when intrapleural pressure remains at subatmospheric pressures (negative barometric values). Clinically, dynamic compression is most commonly associated to the wheezing sound during forced expiration such as in individuals with <a href="Chronic%20obstructive%20pulmonary%20disorder">chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD)</a>.
